A lot of people do

One could easily get the impression that I don't value links since I often claim I don't rely upon links to establish rankings.Many Web sites allow segue points to become page clutter.Note:Â Do you know what a "site" is? Sure you do. Link bombing should be held out as an absolute last resort, and regardless of what euphemisms are used to describe it to a client, the client should be informed of the consequences of playing that game. Using "optimized keywords" in link anchor text creates link bombs, which produce results such as those for the infamous "miserable failure" search. But there are more esoteric things, the secondary content that binds the parts of the page together.There are many ways to create Visibility. Write an introductory article on your established SEO Web site. And while link wheel it's true that any SEO campaign can be designed to implement less than all four fundamental principles, in reality that means such an SEO campaign would limp along rather than surge ahead. It provides a legitimate opportunity for conferring non-search traffic2. But many sites lack the appropriate hierarchical balance to help visitors find what they seek. Not so with visitors. You immediately look at new Web sites and know how to leverage the four fundamental principles into your marketing campaign. Once a search expression becomes polluted with link bombing everyone else competing for that expression gets sucked into the link black hole and is forced to link bomb as well. But links need to be organized just like the content. Yours sucks worse. Don't get caught up in the "Does branding work?" brouhaha. Page clutter is meaningless, time-wasting, ugly drivel. This discussion of linkage is not concerned with the value or benefits of paid link advertising._2. However, many SEOs today foolishly and needlessly worry about the possible linkwheel service negative impact of "internal linkage".Every link should serve three purposes:1.On-page optimization obviates the need for link bombing, which is what most SEOs do with their link building campaigns today. Keyword research is fundamental to understanding what potential visitors need to draw them into a site. None of them are more vital than the others. So do I. To a search engine there is no such thing as "internal linkage" -- not in the sense we mean. No SEO campaign should ignore any of these areas. Use your on-going media campaign for your own business to mention new client sites.VisibilityÂ Visibility is an intangible aspect of search engine optimization, but it is every bit as important as the other three fundamental principles. They are all equally important. Banner ads still exist today because they do work. Nonetheless, many people new to SEO still don't fully appreciate the importance mininet of knowing the difference between the words they feel are important and the words other people use to find sites like theirs. Competent Web designers, having no knowledge of SEO, typically minimize page clutter. Not yet. A lot of people do.Links are the first link wheel service line of advertising for every Web site. If you linkwheel service don't have an on-going media campaign, stop linkwheel wondering why no one has ever heard of you.And finally there are links. And it should have a call to action, like "Shoot the monkey".Intra-site organization is important in two ways.Without links, there is no World Wide Web.And if they don't practice the four fundamental principles, you are miles ahead of their game.To date, search engine technical papers only speak of "hosts" and "neighborhoods" and "sibling pages mininet ". Page clutter can make it difficult for search engines to index appropriate content, however.On-page content organization falls into two areas. Organizing the content is the challenge.What people are searching for should guide Web designers in creating new content. Just because you get links from sites with a Toolbar PageRank of 9 doesn't mean the site will be validated. The average mediocre site only suffers from an acceptable amount of page clutter. Segue points are not necessarily indexable content. While there is value in this perspective for the SEO, there is no substitute for understanding the special jargon that may be necessary to capture primary search traffic for a given market. Content Organization has to satisfy visitors you bring to the site more than the search engines. But guess what? Search engines doÂ notÂ know what a "site" is.LinksÂ Anyone can build links. These can be incidental things; call themÂ segue points.Keyword ResearchÂ Too much attention is given to "key words" and too little attention is given to "research". Most Web sites have page clutter. There are simple things like title tags, bolded text, Hx header tags (if you use them), link anchor text, etc.Content Organization looks at both intra-site and on-page factors. Worse, you are doing things the hard way and creating more work for yourself needlessly.Each of these fundamental principles deserves further discussion in fine detail._3.Content OrganizationÂ Anyone can create content. Be consistent in the way you organize your sites, and your visitors will quickly learn how to find what they seek. They may be tables or boxes that highlight indexable content. So do the search engine designers. A page can have internal links and that's it.Keyword research gets more attention than visibility and content organization. It helps validate a siteAnything else that a link accomplishes is cream. If you are targeting or optimizing link anchor text because "it improves search results rankings", you are link bombing. Linking is link wheel so poorly understood by the SEO community that it deserves an entire book that focuses on the non-SEO aspects of link relationships. Page clutter alienates visitors. Link anchor text needs to persuade visitors to click on it. SEOs often waste precious link anchor text on needless "optimized keywords" that don't compel visitors to click on the links.When you use the fundamentals consistently, you fall into a natural rhythm.First, as a site grows in content (number of pages), it develops a natural hierarchical structure.Site validationÂ may be handled in more than one way. Link bombing is why most companies that pay for SEO should not be paying for link campaigns by the hour. The SEO community needs to do a better job of educating new members about how to conduct effective keyword research and about the importance of updating that research every 4-6 months per Web site. Recent SEO commentaries have begun addressing the "tail" of search expression data. [img]http://www.dominateseo.net/images/web/home/top10-01.png[/img]Validation means the site has been tagged as "Not spammy" or "Not very spammy" or "acceptably muddled and possibly natural". Buy link wheel banner ads. Most SEOs won't do this. It helps search engines crawl and index a site3. Here are three simple, relatively inexpensive methods:1. Every banner should burn the URL into the viewer's mind.A competent SEO doesn't need to link bomb a site to the top of search results that haven't been link bombed already. Just don't look for click-throughs. You may not get the top ranking for every targeted search expression, but your task becomes easier because you are not only spreading the risk of failure across more resources, therefore increasing your chances of success, but you raise the bar -- the level of challenge and difficulty -- for your competitors.Four Fundamental Principles of SEOHere is a quick introduction to the Fundamentals of SEO.Every site needs links from other (previously indexed) sites in order to be crawled and indexed by the search engines. A lot of people do. The only difference between you and someone more famous than you is that the other person has a better media campaign, even if it's sporadic and disorganized. Good intra-site organization makes it easier to design a redundant navigation system (redundancy linkwheel is important, link wheel service as it reducespage isolation). So do your visitors. If you have a site with 100 pages or more of content, you have a complex collection of documents. One misplaced or missing character can change a page's internal structural substantially, preventing one or more search engines from indexing the page properly.Intra-site organization also educates visitors.Without links, the search engines have to rely on URL submission (which is unpleasantly vulnerable to spam even with pictographic validation). Validation is the cure for the "Sandbox Effect". But if you've been building your own visibility, you should be using it to leverage your customers' visibility. Search engines do a pretty good job of sifting through poorly organized content so you have flexibility there.Every site needs links from other (previously validated) sites in order to be validated by the search engines. They may be non-clickable images such as arrows pointing the way.. Keywords are meaningless until you know how they fit into the big picture. Validation means the site will be able to confer PageRank and link reputation (as Matt Cutts puts it) to other sites
